Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Pama-Nyungan Reconstruction and the Prehistory of Australia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The earliest detailed records of Australia's indigenous languages date from approximately two hundred years ago, and therefore our only access to the prehistory of Australia's indigenous past is through reconstruction in archeology and linguistics. While we know that humans have lived in Australia for more than 40,000 years, we do not know how speakers of the 250 currently attested languages came to live where they do today. This project uses linguistic evidence to trace the history of Aboriginal people in prehistoric times. Systematic similarities between words in these languages can be used to reconstruct various properties of prehistoric languages. These techniques will be used to determine the structure of the Pama-Nyungan language family, which will shed light on prehistoric population movements.

Australia's linguistic prehistory is important for several reasons. It has been claimed that methods developed for Europe and the Americas do not work in Australia. If true, such a finding would be highly important, since these methods are based on properties of language change which until now have been assumed to be universal. However, preliminary work indicates that Australian languages show the same characteristics that we find elsewhere. Small speech community size, widespread multilingualism, and other factors have obscured relationships between these languages. These languages are an excellent laboratory for modeling what language change might have been like before the spread of agricultural communities. If we are ever going to be able to model accurately what prehistoric global language spread might have looked like, we need to understand how it operated in Australia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has laid the foundations for a new way of investigating language prehistory: detailed, language-specific comparisons using the comparative method, combined with large scale mathematical and computational studies. While the focus of the grant has been on a single geographical area, the results have implications for general theories of language change.

Archeology is a well-known way of finding out about the past. But digging up and analyzing ancient sites is only one way to investigate history and prehistory. We can also use data from modern languages. Because languages change regularly and systematically, researchers can 'undo' those changes to discover what earlier stages might have looked like. It is also possible to use evidence from language geography to uncover where people moved, who they traded with, and how they interacted. Research in this project has refined tools to answer all these questions. In particular, this research has shown that a class of apparent exceptions to general theories of language change is not, in fact, anomalous. 

A major product of the grant include more than fifteen academic articles. These articles describe the work of the grant, major findings, and tools for linguistic analysis. My institutional website contains a list of publications, many with links to online preprints or publications. Another major outcome of the grant is the development of a 775,000 word database of Australian Aboriginal languages. This database is the largest lexical comparative research resource in existence. It has turned Australian languages from a backwater of historical study to a major testing ground for new theories; in many cases, it is now one of the best areas to test ideas about language change. Other materials resulting from the grant include scripts for data processing and language learning materials.

The grant has had broader impacts in several areas. One is in training students in linguistic research. Undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students have worked on sub-projects and through the grant have been given a hands-on introduction to research. Several students have coauthored and published journal articles, and have gone on to apply their skills to work on languages in other regions, including in the Americas. 

Another area of broader impact has been making it easier for native speakers and community members to access language materials. Aboriginal groups have been historically disenfranchised and excluded from access to the results of research about their culture and languages, and this grant has made much material more accessible. The grant has also aided in the preservation of highly endangered languages and the reanalysis of archival materials.

Finally, the career award has opened up many new questions about how and why language changes, how that change can be studied, and how we can preserve linguistic diversity for the greatest benefit to both speakers and science.
